cellularAutomata.interfaces
Interface Rule<T extends Point>

Type Parameters:
T - A point in the concrete dimension (i.e. 1D, 2D) that the automaton runs in. Should be a strict subclass of Point.
All Known Implementing Classes:
LifeRule
public interface Rule<T extends Point>

Defines a ruleset for a single cellular automaton. The ruleset should be type instantiated with a subclass of Point, which specifies the concrete dimension of the automaton. This class is responsible for specifying a starting state of the world, and giving a function from a neighborhood around a cell to the new state of the cell after one step.

Author:
Kunal Desai, James Grugett, Prasanth Somasundar

Method Summary
 State<T> getInitialState()
          Specifies the initial state of the world.
 int getNeighborhoodSize()
          Lets the framework know how large the neighborhood around a cell should be that is used to determine what the next state of that cell is.
 T getOrigin()
          Returns the origin (0,0, etc.) in the coordinate system used by the ruleset.
 int stepCell(Neighborhood<T> n)
          The primary function of the rule that takes a neighborhood of size specified by the user in getNeighborhoodSize(), and returns a new state that the center of the neighborhood n should step to.
 

Method Detail

stepCell

int stepCell(Neighborhood<T> n)
The primary function of the rule that takes a neighborhood of size specified by the user in getNeighborhoodSize(), and returns a new state that the center of the neighborhood n should step to.

Parameters:
n - a neighborhood around a cell, which is used to determine the new state of the cell.
Returns:
the new state of the center of Neighborhood n

getOrigin

T getOrigin()
Returns the origin (0,0, etc.) in the coordinate system used by the ruleset. In a 2-D grid, (0,0) represents the top left corner, and in a 1-D grid, (0) is the leftmost point.

Returns:

getNeighborhoodSize

int getNeighborhoodSize()
Lets the framework know how large the neighborhood around a cell should be that is used to determine what the next state of that cell is. For example, Conway's Game of Life uses a neighborhood size of 1.

Formally, if the return value is r, the neighborhood around point (x, y) will be {(a, b) | x-r <= a <= x+r && y-r <= b <= y+r}

Returns:
the size (radius) of the neighborhood that this ruleset uses to determine the next state.

getInitialState

State<T> getInitialState()
Specifies the initial state of the world. The simulation will use this as the starting state for the simulation. It is possible that this state could be modified at run time by the end user of the GUI, but this is required to start the GUI.

Returns:
the initial state of the world.
